body_html:
+1 I think for now we need to reserve the right to make changes to this part of the tf codebase without maintaining a .clone implementation, especially given the lack of internal maintainers.
…
On May 5, 2017 5:45 PM, "Vijay Vasudevan" ***@***.***> wrote: I think for now, given that we don't really have any volunteer maintainers of this code internally, we're going to close this PR; I think the current implementation of GraphDef and state in TensorFlow's python implementation is not very amenable to analysis and correctness, and while what you've done is very neat, it will probably make it very difficult or impossible to move the existing complex python code (control flow, state management) to better implementations (not a proof, but just a gut feeling). I believe some of the work on improving functions and state management will make something equivalent to clone() possible and maintainable, and that's what we really need to make sure we do if we intend to make our users happy. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <#5802 (comment)>, or mute the thread <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABtim4hXvJfm5wuLY7Kd6F2SbPmX1GAXks5r28LFgaJpZM4K6UfI> .
body_text:
+1 I think for now we need to reserve the right to make changes to this
part of the tf codebase without maintaining a .clone implementation,
especially given the lack of internal maintainers.
…
On May 5, 2017 5:45 PM, "Vijay Vasudevan" ***@***.***> wrote:
 I think for now, given that we don't really have any volunteer maintainers
 of this code internally, we're going to close this PR; I think the current
 implementation of GraphDef and state in TensorFlow's python implementation
 is not very amenable to analysis and correctness, and while what you've
 done is very neat, it will probably make it very difficult or impossible to
 move the existing complex python code (control flow, state management) to
 better implementations (not a proof, but just a gut feeling).

 I believe some of the work on improving functions and state management
 will make something equivalent to clone() possible and maintainable, and
 that's what we really need to make sure we do if we intend to make our
 users happy.

 —
 You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
 Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
 <#5802 (comment)>,
 or mute the thread
 <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABtim4hXvJfm5wuLY7Kd6F2SbPmX1GAXks5r28LFgaJpZM4K6UfI>
 .
body:
+1 I think for now we need to reserve the right to make changes to this
part of the tf codebase without maintaining a .clone implementation,
especially given the lack of internal maintainers.

On May 5, 2017 5:45 PM, "Vijay Vasudevan" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I think for now, given that we don't really have any volunteer maintainers
> of this code internally, we're going to close this PR; I think the current
> implementation of GraphDef and state in TensorFlow's python implementation
> is not very amenable to analysis and correctness, and while what you've
> done is very neat, it will probably make it very difficult or impossible to
> move the existing complex python code (control flow, state management) to
> better implementations (not a proof, but just a gut feeling).
>
> I believe some of the work on improving functions and state management
> will make something equivalent to clone() possible and maintainable, and
> that's what we really need to make sure we do if we intend to make our
> users happy.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/5802#issuecomment-299604392>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABtim4hXvJfm5wuLY7Kd6F2SbPmX1GAXks5r28LFgaJpZM4K6UfI>
> .
>
